title: 106_hr583
content: The Act may be cited as the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" and addresses the treatment of Assistant United States Attorneys. The "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" amends the Civil Service Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys in the definition of a law enforcement officer. The Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998 amends the definition of a law enforcement officer under the Federal Employees' Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys. The Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998 expands the definition of an assistant United States attorney under title 5, United States Code, to include those appointed under section 542 of title 28. The Act and its amendments will take effect on the first day of the first applicable pay period after enactment. The Act and its amendments will take effect on the first day of the first applicable pay period after enactment. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. For the purposes of this section, an incumbent is an individual appointed as an Assistant United States Attorney before the effective date of this Act and serving in that capacity on such date. The Department of Justice must provide notice to these individuals regarding their election rights under this Act within 6 months of its effective date. Incumbents have the option to make an election under this Act. An incumbent appointed as an Assistant United States Attorney before the Act's effective date can choose to be treated according to the Act's amendments or as if the Act never existed. Failure to elect on time is treated as an election under the amendments. The election must be made within 90 days of receiving notice under subsection (b). The Act allows incumbents to choose their retirement coverage before any changes take effect, with a deadline of 90 days from receiving notice. No changes will occur until an election is made. If an incumbent elects the option, all service as an Assistant United States Attorney will be affected. The Act allows incumbents to choose their retirement coverage before any changes take effect, with a deadline of 90 days from receiving notice. Service as an Assistant United States Attorney will be treated according to applicable provisions of title 5, United States Code, before and after the effective date of the election. Makeup contributions may be required in addition to other payments. The Department of Justice must remit a specified amount to the Office of Personnel Management for retirement payments, which will then be deposited into the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The Department of Justice must remit a specified amount to the Office of Personnel Management for retirement payments, which will then be deposited into the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The amount to be remitted includes additional individual and Government contributions for Assistant United States Attorneys before the effective date of their election under the Act, plus interest. No individual liability is imposed by this Act or the relevant sections of title 5, United States Code. The Office of Personnel Management will establish regulations to implement the Act, including determining interest on required contributions. The term "Assistant United States Attorney" refers to those appointed under section 542 of title 28, United States Code.
